Changeset 174147372 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Gribēju vēl pieminēt, ka surface=gravel nozīmē "akmeņi" nevis "grunts" un dabā tas izpaužas kā uz ceļa brīvi nobērti akmeņi pa kuriem staigāt apgrūtināti un ar velo braukt gandrīz neiespējami. Tādi mēdz būt uz LVM ceļiem, bet ilglaicīgi tie nesaglabājas, jo tie tiek izbraukāti un sapresēti. Faktiski tādu piemēru ir ļoti maz, parasti nelieli gabali privātīpašumu piebrauktuvēm, kur bez virsmas apstrādes vienkārši akmeņu slānis. Parasti bezseguma lauku ceļi "grantenes", kas varbūt arī kādreiz bijuši ar akmeņiem noklāti, Latvijā ir gandrīz vienmēr compacted.

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:surface%3Dcompacted

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:surface%3Dgravel
Date: 2025-11-03T19:10:21+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174147372

Changeset 174350793 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello,

Please be aware that there may be additional speed limit tags, such as maxspeed:type=sign. When changing speed limits, these need to be updated or removed. For example, for this section https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/428047347 that was 70, but now 50, the maxspeed:type=sign implies there is an actual 50 sign (rather than for example being default urban speed limit maxspeed:type=LV:urban). This value is optional, but it is helpful to understand why certain segments are set to certain values.

What is the speed limit here - is it just the default city speed?

Thanks
Date: 2025-11-09T10:53:42+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174350793

Changeset 174728516 (Comment no. 1) by richlv
Contributor: richlv
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Sveiki, liels paldies par kartes papildinājumiem.
Daļa īsti neatbilst apzīmēšanas nosacījumiem - piemēram, te punkts apzīmēts ar:
description="3 vietas"
landuse=residential
residential=trailer_park

https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/13308189061/history

Tas gan vairāk izklausās pēc treileru autostāvvietas, kas būtu https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:amenity=parking.

Aicinām pievienoties OSM Latvijas kopienas čatam https://osmlatvija.zulipchat.com , kur varētu apspriest šo un citus objektus, lai izvēlētos atbilstošākos apzīmējumus.

Changeset 174847863 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello,

Can you please clarify what you mean by "confusion in public and Riga city council". Like where has public expressed such confusing and who in the Council is having confusion about this? The name has been mentioned in many sources. The location has existed for a long time and there are no plans to remove it, as far as I know. The name also does not have to be official, it just has to be verifiable and used. Besides, it's managed by Rīgas Nami not Council, so the decision to "officially" name it is theirs and they have previously published materials with the name (and for other area around the Central Market), so for all intents, it is the official name.
Date: 2025-11-19T17:15:38+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174847863

RSS (Nov 21 2025 at 12:19):

Changeset 174847863 (Comment no. 2) by rih890
Contributor: rih890
Discussion Comment No.: 2
Comment: Hey, thanks for the reply. Yes, i'm aware of the fact that Rīgas nami, which is a SIA under Riga city municipality, has named this place like this in their spatial developement conception last year and even found they organised one event in this space under this name ("Lietuviešu tirgus" in may 2025). Adjacent street name was also changed to Emīlijas Benjamiņas street last year. But that doesn't change the fact, that acording to rules by Cabinet of Ministers Nr. 455 "Adresācijas noteikumi" street and square names in cities are given by local municipality council. In Riga city there is a special commission of placenames "Rīgas vietvārdu un pilsētvides objektu nosaukumu komisija" which evaluates propositions of giving or changing street and square names and then drafts a resolution for city council to vote on, so the final decision is made by the council. It is unlikely that this commission or council would approve of naming this square like this when there is already a street named similarily adjacent to it and Emīlija Benjamiņa has no direct historical connection to this place, or market in general which makes it even more unlikely to become the official name for this possible square. I will give you one example how this named space already appears on maps circumventing the existing order of things is already misleading map users - in Riga city geoportal georiga.eu basemap layer in many apps is OSM and this square name appears on them where the label is formated in such a way that it seems to be of the same status and importance as any other square in Riga, which is misleading the user. E.g. the same as "Akadēmijas laukums", "Doma laukums" etc. In addition it is important to underline that Riga city historic center (RVC) is a place of special importance as a UNESCO heritage site and even seemingly trivial things like squares are strictly defined in spatial plan of RVC, for example adjacent "Nēģu laukums" appears on the spatial plan. Taking this all in consideration even if it seems trivial it is important that this square does not appear of OSM maps or at the minimum uses a different label formating than other official squares to not mislead the map user.
Date: 2025-11-21T11:33:34+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174847863

RSS (Nov 22 2025 at 00:46):

Changeset 174962332 (Comment no. 1) by NeisBot
Contributor: NeisBot
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Welcome, and thanks for your edits!

I noticed a few unintended crossings between roads and/or between roads and buildings in this changeset. This usually happens when geometry snaps incorrectly. Additionally, changes to tagging (e.g. modifying highway types or adding tags) can lead to unexpected crossings being detected afterwards.

In total, I detected 8 potential crossings.

Problematic elements (top 3 by category):
https://osm.org/way/1452565085 v4 | crossings=8

Dragged Nodes (max 3):
https://osm.org/node/13322641957 v1
https://osm.org/node/13322641951 v1
https://osm.org/node/13322641958 v1

Would you mind revisiting those areas?

#CrossingCheck

https://resultmaps.neis-one.org/osm-change-viz?c=174962332

Changeset 174936743 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Couple you please check the tagging for the ways leading to the bandstand/estrāde. Informal paths are path in unplanned locations that have formed by people walking through location they are not expected to walk (like the correct ones in courtyards here where people walk along grass as shortcuts when there are roads and footways nearby). This never applies to built or expected paths or locations where there isn't infrastructure, like forests. If there are unpaved paths here, they would just be highway=path. If these are paved or somehow built, then they would be highway=footway. You also drew an area here https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1452565074, so whatever the path is, it has to be a asphalted footway then too.
Date: 2025-11-22T10:39:23+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174936743

RSS (Nov 22 2025 at 12:16):

Changeset 174939410 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello,

When drawing road areas, they have to match the same designation (residential, service, tertiary, etc.) as the main road way. These are additional elements to describe the exact road geometry, but they always have to match the main road in all their properties and location. They also have to connect to all the roads that they cross, otherwise they are not linked to the ways in the data properly. I fixed most of these here. They also should not overlap other types of ways, like footways. In general, very few editors draw these because it is a lot of work, easy to make mistakes and very difficult to fix.

For example, something like this https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1452599160 would be completely wrong because this is not a road. Similarly around https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/6661549639 road area overlaps footway.
Date: 2025-11-22T10:32:41+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174939410

RSS (Nov 22 2025 at 12:16):

Changeset 174982149 (Comment no. 1) by somehundred

Comment: Šie divi ceļi īstenībā nav 1. stāvā, bet 2. un 3. Tas ir norādīts ar 'level' birkām. Ceļi beidzas pie logiem. Līdz ar to pievienot ieeju nav pareizi lai gan apstiprinu, ka šajā pusē ir ieejas, taču tās vajag zīmēt atsevišķi.

Jebkurš var pats pārbaudīt klātienē trešā stāva ceļu, ieejot Apollo Kino un uzskāpjot pa kāpnēm, bet diemžēl lai izpētītu 2. stāva ceļu vajag iziet caur elektroniskajiem vārtiem, kur vajag noskenēt kino biļeti.

Changeset 157939259 (Comment no. 4) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 4
Comment: So "living zone" in Latvia is the signed "dzīvojamā zona" (20 speed limit, pedestrian priority, etc.) On OSM these are tagged as living streets (highway=living_street). The speed limit there is always maxspeed=20.

In this case, the roads were tagged as living streets since they were drawn. Then you added 50 speed limit to them, which means either the speed limit was incorrect or the living zone designation was incorrect. I understand now there is no living zone here, so the designation was incorrect.

I have already changed these to regular residential roads since then based on available footage of the area. I added back the 50 limit too now.
Date: 2025-11-27T16:29:37+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/157939259

RSS (Dec 01 2025 at 18:16):

Changeset 175351891 (Comment no. 2) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 2
Comment: Hello,

I have reverted your changeset because it added too many duplicates to the live map data with incorrect values. I kept/restored the nodes that appear to be new elements.

I'm not sure how you are surveying these locations, but please make sure your map is up to date and verify what the EveryDoor map actually shows when you are visiting the location so that you don't add duplicate objects for things that are already mapped. If you want to add names or properties to something already mapped, you will need to select and edit existing objects, not create new ones.

Changeset 172603754 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap

Comment: Sveiki,

Vai varētu precizēt, kas tieši šeit domāts iekartēt? Ir iezīmēts jauns ceļa posms, bet šādi joslas OSM nezīmē atsevišķi, ja tās nav fiziski atdalītas. Arī galvenā ceļa tegi un pagriezienu ierobežojumi tagad ir nepareizi, ja josla ir nodalīta kā atsevišķs neatkarīgs ceļš. Arī tam tad vajag visas vērtības, kā ātruma ierobežojumus u.c.. Komentārā ir par mašīnu masu, bet te gan sanāk kaut kas cits kartēts. Kādā posmā šeit tieši ir šis maxlength=10, jo faktiski tas datos neko neietekmēs izņemot šo papildus posmu. Ceļa bildēs nekādas zīmes es neredzu, vai te kaut kas mainījies kopš vasaras?

RSS (Dec 02 2025 at 00:51):

Changeset 174936836 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Čau,

Šeit gribēju pieminēt par ceļu/ielu nosaukumiem.

Ievadam, Latvijā ir divi biežāk sastopami nosaukumi - ceļu maršrutu nosaukumi un ielu nosaukumi. Maršruts ir piemēram "Ulbroka - Ogre" ar kodu "P5" (tie ir no LVC datiem). Bet ielas nosaukums ir piemēram "Institūta iela" konkrētos posmos (tie ir no VZD kadastra datiem). Tie ir divi savstarpēji neatkarīgi nosaukumi un var būt viens, otrs, abi un neviens (un maršruti vispār var pārklāties).

Tāpēc maršrutus vienmēr kartē kā relāciju, piemēram:
https://www.openstreetmap.org/relation/177573. Arī ielas var kartēt relācijā, bet parasti dati ir pa taisno uz pašām ceļa līnijām. Tas nozīmē, ka ceļiem name= ir primāri ielu nosaukumi nevis maršrutu nosaukumi. Ja posmam nav ielas nosaukuma, tad var arī likt maršruta nosaukumu (bet tas arī nav 100% korekti). Bet kodu noteikti liek tikai ref=.

Piemēram, noņemot šeit pilnībā "Institūta iela" datos tiek pazaudēts ielas nosaukums adresācijai/meklēšanai/navigācijai (piemēram šai ēkai vairs nekur nav tādas ielas https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/120510451). Bet maršruta nosaukumus OSM ir pieņemts likt bez kodiem un citiem "pielikumiem". Jo citādi piemēram kartēs/navigatoros divreiz lasa/rāda "P5". Un arī nosaukuma vai citu birku maiņa arī jāatspoguļo tad relācijā (te gan viss it kā jau ir pareizi).

Pirms tam man liekas te viss bija vairāk vai mazāk pareizi. Varbūt posmi nebija precīzi. Ielas nosaukumu te kaut kad nesen biju izlabojis no VZD datiem. Tagad arī izlaboju.
Date: 2025-12-01T21:55:07+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174936836

RSS (Dec 02 2025 at 18:16):

Changeset 172334938 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Čau,

Zīmējot elementus kā laukumus, lūdzu apvieno (redaktorā C) tos ar iepriekš iezīmētiem punktiem, ja tādi ir. Citādi datos ir nepareizi dubultēti elementi vienam objektam.

Šajā gadījumā zīmējot parkingu https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1432250288 , palika iepriekšējais https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/11662459248 .

Changeset 174847863 (Comment no. 4) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 4
Comment: Sorry for not replying earlier.

The issue is that you are conflating what OSM records and what is "official". OSM is a global geospatial database and while it generally records what is official locally, that doesn't imply that OSM won't map something if it's not official. OSM maps what is "on the ground".[1] So, as in this example, OSM records names if they are shown to exist even conceptually. It doesn't have to be part of VZD address data, nor any Council documents, nor official square designation, nor UNESCO plans, etc. - it just has to verifiably exist.[2] Similarly, a "square" in OSM is not defined based on local designations, but what is there on the ground - broadly, an urban paved area with various urban features around some buildings. You may be used to maps like LĢIA official data layers and Jāņa sēta renders and even Google/Apple maps that gather their data from primarily official sources. But OSM is not limited to that, which is the whole point of OSM - to be an open map that isn't restricted like that. OSM is often much more detailed and record many more features and data about them. For example, just the name tagging itself has dozens of variants.[3] In general, OSM maps what is correct rather than what may or may not appear when rendered on some map.[4]

Your reply is quite long and you touch upon a lot of different concepts, so I cannot really reply to every point. For example, features that are part of UNESCO would be recorded as heritage tagging scheme[5] as UNESCO sites, VKPAI sites, etc. You wouldn't judge what is or isn't a heritage site or location (or name) based on what some particular map renders, but whether it is tagged as heritage site and associated with a particular heritage-tracking body. The same argument applies to all the other points - having a name is not limited to any particular source or feature.

In any case, this name can be easily verified as used by sources. This isn't even the typical case where we can't find any mentions. This is more than enough to include the name.

[1] https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Ground_truth

[2] https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Verifiability

[3] https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Names

[4] https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tagging_for_the_renderer

[5] https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:heritage
Date: 2025-12-14T14:59:34+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174847863

RSS (Dec 14 2025 at 18:14):

Changeset 176153378 (Comment no. 5) by HellMap

Un arī ieliku linkus gan vispārīgi gan konkrēti Latvijai, kur OSM skaidri nodala, kādus ceļus atzīmē kā dzīvojamo ielu. Ja nav dzīvojamās zonas zīmes, tad highway=living_street Latvijā neliek.

Changeset 176186955 (Comment no. 3) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 3
Comment: traffic_signals:direction luksoforiem uz ceļiem tiek lietots, lai norādītu, kurš galvenais luksofors attiecas kuram braukšanas virzienam transportlīdzekļu un gājēju navigācijai. Ar to nenorāda atkārtotus un papildus luksoforus. Vērtība both vispār gandrīz nekad nevar būt, jo tas nozīmētu, ka no abām pusēm vienā vietā ir jāapstājas, bet pa vidu nekā nav. Divreiz iekartēti luksofori tad nozīmētu, ka šeit ir 2 reizes jāapstājas pie luksofora, kas tā noteikti nav, jo atkārtotie luksofori šeit strādā vienā ciklā.

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:highway%3Dtraffic_signals#Tag_all_incoming_ways
Date: 2025-12-20T20:07:15+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/176186955

RSS (Dec 21 2025 at 00:57):

Changeset 176186330 (Comment no. 3) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 3
Comment: Tad punkts ir jānomaina uz pareizām birkām, kā piemēram amenity=events_venue ( https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:amenity%3Devents_venue ) .

Pēc https://visit.jelgava.lv/lv/sv-trisvienibas-tornis/vestures-ekspozicijas skatoties, šeit ir arī ekspozīcijas/muzejs. Izskatās, ka šeit ir arī restorāns. Visticamāk, tie visi jānorāda kā atsevišķi punkti, lai tie ir gan datos, gan meklētājā. Bet dzēst gan šo punktu nevajadzēja, jo tagad nav palicis nekas un nosaukums vairs nav atrodams.
Date: 2025-12-20T19:54:10+01:00

Changeset 176206717 (Comment no. 3) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 3
Comment: Bet tev no paša sākuma nekas nav jādzēš. Neatkarīgi no tā, vai tu zīmē kaut ko šeit vai citur atpakaļ, nevajag pirms tam neko masveidā dzēst. Var dzēst, ja elementi vairs sen neeksistē vai ir pilnīgi nepareizi. Bet šeit un citās izmaiņām elementi jau bija iezīmēti. Ja kaut kas ar tiem ir nepareizi, tad izlabo tos.

Bet nevar dzēst - tiek pazaudēta elementu vēsture un izmaiņu secība, elementu numuri un piesaiste citās datu bāzēs, tavu izmaiņu kopu pārskatamība, citu kartētāju darbs un izmaiņu pārskatamība, to avoti un atsauces. Nav pamatota iemesla šādās vietās kaut ko dzēst.

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Keep_the_history
Date: 2025-12-21T13:01:46+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/176206717

RSS (Dec 22 2025 at 18:16):

Changeset 176232973 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Sveiki vēlreiz, šai un citām ietvēm segums nav sett, bet paving_stones. sett OSM nozīmē ir cobblestone variants - noapaļotu vienmērīgi saliktu veselu akmeņu bruģakmens. Latvijā gandrīz visur jaunie segumi ir tikai paving_stones ar vienlaidus ciešiem "ķieģeļiem", bet sett vai unhewn_cobblestone no akmeņiem ir palicis tikai vēsturiskās vietās vai arī, ja veidots kaut kādiem dekoratīviem mērķiem. Jelgavā piemēram pie pils vai vecajā centrā ir pāris ielas un celiņi sett, bet kopš tā būvētais praktiskās vietās ir gandrīz tikai paving_stones.

paving_stones: https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=601352485625022&focus=photo

sett: https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=556798790826629&focus=photo / https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=4121163301493349&focus=photo

unhewn_cobblestone: https://www.mapillary.com/app/?pKey=552224007143304&focus=photo

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:surface%3Dpaving_stones
Date: 2025-12-22T17:06:52+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/176232973

RSS (Dec 23 2025 at 00:53):

Changeset 176232973 (Comment no. 3) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 3
Comment: Izskatās, ka redaktorā tulkojums latviski lietots ar "bruģis" = sett un ar "bruģakmens" = paving_stones. Tas gan nav pareizs tulkojums vai vismaz ļoti mulsinošs. (Tīri precīzi "bruģis" ir ceļa seguma veids, bet "bruģakmeņi" ir paši akmeņi, kas var būt betons, plakans, apaļš.) Šeit izskatās, ka tulkojums ir vienkārši nepareizs un otrādi ielikts.

Skatoties latviešu tulkojumus, ļoti daudz diemžēl izskatās nepareizi (iespējams mašīntulkoti), tāpēc laikam pirmreizēji būtu vērts apskatīt kādu vērtību reāli tas tulkojums ieliek. Personīgi, man redaktors angļu valodā, tāpēc neesmu sastapies ar šo līdz šim un nebiju aizdomājies par šo.

Es pamēģināšu redaktorā tulkojumu izlabot un iesniegt labojumu. Pagaidām gan būs kā ir.
Date: 2025-12-22T19:24:13+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/176232973

Changeset 176282967 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello,

As mentioned before, please do not retag areas into farmyards unless that's what they actually are. You are not just adding, but mass-converting residential areas to farmyards. Farmyards on OSM have a specific meaning and not what you are mapping. Please read what https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:landuse=farmyard says. You are creating incorrect map data making it look like Latvia is covered with farmyards when in reality most of these locations do not engage in any farming or livestock keeping.
Date: 2025-12-30T11:24:32+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/176282967

RSS (Dec 30 2025 at 12:21):

Changeset 174847863 (Comment no. 6) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 6
Comment: To return to the original query, to really simplify it:

Rīgas Nami calls it "Benjamiņas laukums". They manage the area, so they can call it and its features whatever they want. Per OSM Verifiability principle, it is shown that a feature's name comes from a reputable source. No other source gives it a different name. Tag name is used for such names. Therefore, name=Benjamiņas laukums.

I linked you several relevant pages. If you don't think the name should be here, you should demonstrate how it conflicts with OSM and not some other map or plan.

The one relevant thing to OSM you mentioned, which could be a concern, is that it "misleads users that it is infact official name/adress of this square". But OSM makes no such claim. This was the very first question I asked you that you never replied to. Who are these users? Who from Riga Council is confused?
Date: 2025-12-30T11:12:19+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/174847863

RSS (Dec 31 2025 at 12:20):

Changeset 174847863 (Comment no. 7) by rih890
Contributor: rih890
Discussion Comment No.: 7
Comment: The fact is it probably does not conflict with any OSM rules, but purpose of any map is to inform the users not mislead them. I gave you an example, which is the only reason I'm here and I can repeat it if you wish - this name appears on many maps that uses OSM data, for example in Riga city geoportal georiga.eu basemap layer in many apps is OSM and this square name appears (currently it's updated to not include it) on them where the label is formated in such a way that it seems to be of the same status and importance as any other square in Riga, which is misleading the user. E.g. the same as "Akadēmijas laukums", "Doma laukums" etc (which are actual adresses, like Doma laukums 1). To elaborate, multiple collegues at Riga City Developement department, especially those working with Historic Center of Riga and spatial planning have expressed concerns with this name, that's why I'm here trying to resolve this somehow. Now looking at the map and not having technical knowledge of OSM I would say that all the square names proposed by Rīgas Nami could be formatted similarily to how pavilions are formatted, since they are part of the market and map users clearly differentiate that these are part of the market and not squares/adresses like other "laukumi" in Riga.

Changeset 176731684 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello,

Please don't change compacted surface to unpaved. "Unpaved" is a generic term - it can be anything from mud to gravel. Compacted is a more accurate value than unpaved, if this road is compacted (which most unpaved rural roads in Latvia are). By removing this value, you are making the data less precise. If your navigator doesn't understand this value, then contact the developers and ask them to fix it. If anything, compacted is a better surface than what you can assume from plain unpaved.

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:surface#Unpaved
Date: 2026-01-02T18:24:19+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/176731684

RSS (Jan 05 2026 at 18:17):

RSS (Jan 10 2026 at 12:18):

Changeset 177037357 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello,

Thanks for you map changes! A few notes.

It's not necessary to specify source on each road/feature. It is enough to specify the sources for the changeset when uploading. In fact, having sources on elements makes it harder to maintain the data long-term, since there would be way too many and they will go out of date quickly.

When drawing roads to individual properties, these should be driveways highway=service + service+driveway not tracks. Tracks are land access roads in forests and meadows and such. While driveways are "final" approach roads that lead to properties. There is some variation and it's often necessary to check the cadaster layer to see what properties roads pass through.

Some of the roads you drew did not connect to the other roads, like https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/1465690426 , which means they would not work for navigation. Make sure to snap road connection in the editor (there usually is a warning before upload).

I have fixed the above issues.

I should note that a lot of the data on the map, especially in rural areas is old and might not be correctly tagged, so be aware if using it as examples.

Cheers
Date: 2026-01-10T10:41:29+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/177037357

RSS (Jan 10 2026 at 18:15):

Changeset 169276126 (Comment no. 2) by Mezonens
Contributor: Mezonens
Discussion Comment No.: 2
Comment: Hi!

The street name was assigned incorrectly, because according to VARIS (Valsts adrešu reģistra informācijas sistēma) data, this is not 18. Novembra iela. This road segment does not have any official name at all. It also has no name according to LĢIA data.

  1. Novembra iela runs perpendicular to this street. A living street cannot be given a name that does not apply to it just because such streets are expected to have a name. I mapped the living street only up to the relevant road sign. The continuation beyond that point as an unclassified road seems logical to me.

RSS (Jan 20 2026 at 18:20):

Changeset 169276126 (Comment no. 7) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 7
Comment: Those don't have an official name either. Only the main highway has a street name in the VZD street line data.

VZD and VARIS are the same "source", broadly speaking. VZD is the state agency that maintains the VAR(IS) address database.

For the purposes of SC, these should normally be tagged noname=yes. But, as you say, street signs on the ground are ambiguous, so how could one know. Ideally, we will map all street names from the database directly first, so SC doesn't really need to offer this quest (like they don't offer some other address-related ones anymore in Latvia).

From experience, in Latvia may be 1% of street lines have offshoots into side roads. Normally, these are either not named or named differently. There are many crazy streets layouts, but most often street lines are just continuous lines without branching. So if you see the name on the main road, offshoots more than likely don't actually have the same name, at least in the official data.
Date: 2026-01-20T17:37:56+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/169276126

RSS (Jan 21 2026 at 00:56):

Changeset 169276126 (Comment no. 10) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 10
Comment: That topo map isn't the same as VZD data. I'm not entirely sure how they assemble and edit it and how often (I've never looked into it). I don't think kartes.lgia.lv actually has any map with street lines, because the lines are often messy. You would need to parse https://data.gov.lv/dati/dataset/varis-atvertie-dati or use one of the internal layers from LGIA/LVM WMS service such as [1].

Many roads are represented by just one line, so when in reality there are several parallel roads, it's often down to mapper judgement. For example, the northwest end of that street is actually Stacijas iela, which turns around the corner.

[1] https://lvmgeoserver.lvm.lv/geoserver/ows?FORMAT=image/jpeg&VERSION=1.3.0&SERVICE=WMS&REQUEST=GetMap&LAYERS=public:Orto_LKS,publicwfs:Kadastra_karte,publicwfs:arisstreet,publicwfs:arisroad,publicwfs:arisbuilding&STYLES=&CRS={proj}&WIDTH={width}&HEIGHT={height}&BBOX={bbox}
Date: 2026-01-20T22:55:18+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/169276126

RSS (Jan 23 2026 at 00:55):

Changeset 177928785 (Comment no. 1) by somehundred
Contributor: somehundred
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hello! There are a few issues with these changes.

First, you deleted some tags for no reason. check_date tag specifies the last time when a place was surveyed in person. Editors like EveryDoor add it automatically when a change to the place is made. Removing outdoor_seating also wasn't needed. The place indeed doesn't have outdoor seating.

Second, don't completely delete places that have closed. Instead, remove all relevant tags from the place and leave only shop=vacant or disused:\=\ Choose whatever fits the best. This solution records the history of a place.
Here's documentation about these two tags:

https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:disused:\*
https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:shop%3Dvacant

Lastly, I want to discuss changing the sia leno s from bar to a cafe. I was physically inside there and confirmed that it's a bar despite the fact that there's a sign outside saying that it's a cafe. The only things available without waiting were drinks and a small selection of snacks. The main course had to be ordered from a menu. What was the reason to change the place's tagging to cafe?

P.S. Please let me know if you're okay to talk in Latvian.
Date: 2026-01-31T17:04:19+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/177928785

Changeset 178017392 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hey!

Thanks for fixing these.

Don't forget that Bing in Latvia is misaligned by 1-2 meters. Something like -1.1, -0.9 in editor. You would generally compare it with LVM, which should be precise.

By the way, noexit=yes is basically for telling other mappers (and verification tools) that "it's not obvious, but this doesn't connect to anything". For obvious terminating connections (like at a fence) or for places where road turns into a footway or something, there shouldn't be a noexit. It's literally the opposite there - an exit ;)
Date: 2026-02-02T17:52:53+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178017392

Changeset 178101197 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hi,

Thanks for your edits.

I fixed some minor issues.

One note I wanted to mentioned: it's not really desired or strictly correct to specify horse (or other) legal access values on random paths unless they differ from country defaults or have additional signage or rules. In Latvia, there are almost no locations with special horse-related restrictions. This is true for foot and bicycle too - few locations are signed as "no pedestrians" or "bicycles only" or similar. Unless a path or footway has special restrictions or it's not obvious that the access is public, there shouldn't be additional values. Especially since "unknown" implies that there may actually be restrictions, just not yet surveyed.
Date: 2026-02-05T11:13:43+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178101197

Changeset 178755304 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Please note that crossings are almost never informal if they are a continuation of sidewalks, like in this location with lowered kerbs. In this case, these are just unmarked crossings.
Date: 2026-02-19T11:08:10+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178755304

Date: 2026-02-21T09:19:33+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178736600

RSS (Feb 21 2026 at 12:22):

Changeset 178755304 (Comment no. 3) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 3
Comment: Hey, no worries. It's a little bit confusing, because there are so many types of crossings worldwide, but OSM also has to capture local variations in a standard way. There is some subjectiveness to this. The difference in this location is the intention of the crossing. Generally in cities, if there are lowered kerbs and/or the crossing is a logical connection between the sidewalks, then from OSM perspective it is a crossing, specifically one that is unmarked - no signs or zebra. Think of it in terms of navigation - would someone walking along the sidewalk cross the road here normally? In contrast, an informal crossing is something where a crossing is not intended/planned/built/expected at all, but is still legal and people frequently use it.

There's a brief explanation at https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:crossing%3Dinformal#Similar_tags
Date: 2026-02-21T11:26:18+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178755304

RSS (Feb 22 2026 at 01:07):

Changeset 178890592 (Comment no. 1) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hi,

Just wanted to let you know, while I think this change (secondary -> primary) is probably correct, please be careful when relying on official documents for such changes, especially city/municipality ones. They have their own classification, rules, principles that vary between locations, municipalities and cities, and they do not always match OSM classification, which is based on functional usage on the ground and not things like for example planning documents, which may range from accurate to purely hypothetical. For major changes, it is best to discuss such edits first.
Date: 2026-02-23T19:41:55+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178890592

RSS (Feb 24 2026 at 01:05):

Changeset 178974785 (Comment no. 4) by Taya_S
Contributor: Taya_S
Discussion Comment No.: 4
Comment: Hi Alexey_ND,

Please don't perform edits just to satisfy some validator without understanding what the warning is for. Warnings are just tools that \can\ be used to reveal data issues. Just because there is a warning, doesn't mean there are any issues. Long ways on their own are not an issue that needs to be systematically fixed.

Furthermore, any such edits should first meet the Automated Edits Guidelines requirement https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Automated_Edits_code_of_conduct

Best regards,
Taya Snijder,
On behalf of the OSMF Data Working Group
Date: 2026-02-25T07:39:30+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178974785

RSS (Feb 25 2026 at 18:49):

Changeset 178974785 (Comment no. 5) by Alexey_ND
Contributor: Alexey_ND
Discussion Comment No.: 5
Comment: OSM does not enforce a strict, technical maximum length for ways or segments, but practical constraints and community standards dictate optimal sizes for data accuracy, processing, and routing.
Sections of tens and hundreds of kilometers in length are inconvenient for many purposes. Is this even normal?
The validators is just a tool. I personally decide what to do.
So, what's the problem with this edit?
Sincerely, Alexey.
Date: 2026-02-25T18:15:03+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178974785

for HellMap

Date: 2026-02-25T19:51:54+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178974785

RSS (Feb 26 2026 at 01:04):

Changeset 178975010 (Comment no. 3) by HellMap
Contributor: HellMap
Discussion Comment No.: 3
Comment: Hi, no worries. In general, it is best not to survey/tag things in winter that are impossible to determine. But if you are local and you know the surface, then that's fine. On aerial, these look like typical dirt informal paths.

Ground is more generic that dirt. It just means there's no man-made surface. For example, in a forest you might have a mix of grass, dirt, roots, pebbles, leaves, moss, etc. - so it's not really possible to say what one thing it is exactly. While specifically dirt is just the exposed earth layer without vegetation. It's rare in cities to have actual recognisable grass paths - they get quickly stomped out.

In the case of real-life dirt+grass mix, I would still put it as dirt, because that's the surface that indicates the path through the grass and differentiates it from the surrounding grass. Personally, I just leave it as ground most of the time exactly because of the question you ask. It's never going to be precise for these informal paths that are just exposed and stomped dirt lines through what used to be grass. I just recommend not putting specifically grass, but both generic ground or more exact dirt is fine.
Date: 2026-02-25T22:06:31+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178975010

RSS (Feb 26 2026 at 18:36):

Changeset 178888851 (Comment no. 1) by mueschel
Contributor: mueschel
Discussion Comment No.: 1
Comment: Hi,
it's not common to prefix the gtfs codes with a country code. Usually it is added at the end, mostly combined with a region of operator information.
See e.g. this list of tags that are used in other places:
https://taginfo.openstreetmap.org/search?q=gtfs%3Astop_id
Date: 2026-02-28T17:31:48+01:00
http://www.openstreetmap.org/changeset/178888851
